content.description:
Start off of the boulder below & left of the first bolt. Make a reachy clip at the first bolt, and continue up to the ledge below the second bolt, placing a couple cams along the way. Get a rest here, and then keep cranking up the steep wall with flawless stone and technical moves as the pump builds.

EDIT: I added 1 bolt to the direct start which is definitely the way to do this thing. Adds a few .10+ moves up to the ledge before the second bolt. There are two places for gear between bolts 1 and 2 which are easily scoped from the ground.
content.protection: 9 bolts, a couple cams up to 1 1/2" between bolts 1 and 2, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is on the East side of Bird Rock, best approached from the north side of the crag. Start approximately 20' left of the splitter finger crack of

Go For It

. Step off a small boulder to clip the first bolt.

content.description: Clip a bolt off of the big boulder and continue on to the striking finger & thin hand crack with bomber gear. When the juggy face holds and crack end, face climb past two bolts to the anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 2", 3 bolts, plus a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the leftmost route on the east side of Bird Rock. Look for the neon green lichen with a perfect crack. Start left of the huge chimney.

content.description:
Phoenix Lite is every wannabe hardman’s favorite (fictional) lite beer.

Begin on perched boulder, then execute a classy mantel.  Now you’re cruising through steeper terrain on great holds. Crimp it through the granite wave, and then crack a cold one.
content.protection: Brass and small cams for start, then bolts and loweroffs. Use a double draw on bolt 3. Bring a cooler with ice.
content.location: It is the leftmost route on this wall.

content.description: Find the striking finger crack starting way down low on the right side of the wall. Climb the finger  crack to a ledgy section and a rest. Launch up the steep, intermittent crack systems & patina with tricky and pumpy gear placements. This is an amazing trad route if you have the guns!
content.protection: Pro to 1 1/2", RPs, extra wires & small cams, and a 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
This is on the right side of the wall, next route right of

Thunderbird

.

content.description: Work up past 3 bolts via the arete or directly up the crack type feature. Pull the roof, and sink a cam on the right. Clip the next bolt, and pull a long move past the overlap. Work up following bolts with another cam placement before the anchor.
content.location:
This route is located to the left of

Thunderbird

. This side is mostly in the shade, pick a warm day or cold hands...send it.

content.description: Traverse up and right on some loose looking blocks to the first bolt. Go straight up through the right side of the roof to gain the next bolt and overhanging wall. Juggy face holds and cracks lead to the top.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a standard rack to a #3 (BD).
content.location:
This route starts ~20' left of

Quackmore Duck

.

content.description:
Eat your Wheaties for this one. "

"Crowtein"

is a wild, dynamic ride of a route and one of the more steeper routes in the entire South Platte.

Stickclip the low chain draw (the first bolt under the roof helps for the belayer whilst figuring out the move), and begin the fight.

A large entrance move get you to a jug where an incredibly core intensive boulder problem awaits (clocks in around

V8

). Gain the jugs above the chain, and surf left with some easier climbing to a stand-able ledge.

Leaving the ledge lies another cryptic and incredibly dynamic boulder problem (

V7

). This is stylistic of something you'd find on southern sandstone. Clip the chain draw, and cruise easier moves/holds up the tiered roof finish.

Top out the cliff for full value, and scramble down the chimney to the east!

This is a fun, bouldery line in a beautiful setting with tons of exposure to boot up high.
content.protection: 6 bolts. The first bolt under the roof is best used for directional to help belaying/decrypting lower crux. I highly advise using a stickclip to remove it once the climber is past the lower crux in order to reduce drag.
content.location:
It is located just to the right of "

Bird Law

" and can be identified by a chain draw at the second bolt/roof feature.

content.description: Climb an arete past the second bolt, then traverse right, and put your cam in a hand crack. Go up past bolts to the chain anchors.
content.location: Go to the east side of Bird Rock, this is the first bolted route you come to.

content.description:
*A stickclip is recommended.

Start low with a boulder problem that can be done a few different ways. All involve some stretchy movement and stemming.

Mantel up into the alcove, then pull a small roof, and traverse right on good holds. Steep 5.11 jug terrain lies ahead on impeccable stone.

This is a fun route with quality movement in a serene setting.
content.location:
Upon hiking up to the backside of Bird Rock, locate the the steepest feature of the cliff located uphill past the break in the wall.

This route lies plumb line in the middle of the wall. Utilize photos for reference.

The first route on the upper tier is currently a project.
